RBI has announced certain regulatory measures to mitigate the burden of debt servicing brought about by disruptions on account of COVID-19 pandemic and to ensure the continuity of viable businesses. It was felt that there may be a temporary disruption in the cash-flows and#Comma in some cases loss of income#Comma for the businesses/ individuals and the present measures work to bring relief to those businesses / individuals.

The relief is available for credit card payments also.#Newline #NewlineIn case of credit card dues#Comma there is a requirement to pay minimum amount and#Comma if it is not paid#Comma it gets reported to credit bureaus. In view of the RBI circular#Comma the overdues in the credit card account do not get reported to the credit bureaus for a period of three months.#Newline #NewlineHowever#Comma interest will be charged by the credit card issuer on unpaid amount. You should check from your card-provider#Comma to arrive at interest payable. #Newline #NewlineAlthough no penal interest will be charged during this period#Comma you must remember that the interest rate on credit card dues are normally much higher compared to normal bank credit and you should take a decision accordingly.

Rescheduling of principal can be done for a period of three months falling due between 1 March 2020 and 31 May 2020. For example#Comma where the last instalment of a term loan falls due for payment of on say 1st March#Comma it will become payable on 1 June 2020.#Newline For EMI-based term loans#Comma it will be three EMIs falling due between 1 March 2020 and 31 May 2020 and the tenor will be extended by three months and have to be repaid during the extended period#Comma as per the example under (2) above.
Yes#CommaYou can extend it for all such term loans without the need for seeking deviations or approvals.

You may take the benefits under this package if there is a disruption in your cash flows or there is loss of income. However#Comma you must take into account that the interest on the loans#Comma though not mandatorily payable immediately and gets postponed by three months#Comma continues to accrue on your account and results in higher cost.#Newline #NewlineTo give you a perspective#Comma suppose your loan outstanding is Rs100#Comma000 and you are charged 12% rate of interest on your loans#Comma then every month you are liable to pay Rs1#Comma000 as interest. In case you opt not to service the interest every month#Comma you are liable to pay interest at 12% p.a. and accordingly you will pay Rs3#Comma030.10 at the end of 3rd month.#Newline #NewlineSimilarly#Comma in case the interest rate is 10%#Comma you are required to pay Rs833 per month or Rs2#Comma521 after three months.

This option to defer payments on loans is a relief granted to borrowers due to disruption caused due to the unprecedented outbreak of COVID-19. However#Comma the borrower has the option to continue scheduled payments during this moratorium; or avail of the benefit of the Moratorium.

The relief is available for credit card payments also.#Newline #NewlineIn case of credit card dues#Comma there is a requirement to pay minimum amount and#Comma if it is not paid#Comma it gets reported to credit bureaus. In view of the RBI circular#Comma the overdues in the credit card account do not get reported to the credit bureaus for a period of three months.#Newline #NewlineHowever#Comma interest will be charged by the credit card issuer on unpaid amount. You should check from your card-provider#Comma to arrive at interest payable. #Newline #NewlineAlthough no penal interest will be charged during this period#Comma you must remember that the interest rate on credit card dues are normally much higher compared to normal bank credit and you should take a decision accordingly.
A moratorium is a temporary suspension of activity until future events warrant lifting of the suspension or related issues have been resolved.
